mods.note: Notes on Tribes and Boundaries. Note by Mr. J. R. FitzGerald, First Assistant to the A.G.G. for Beluchistan, 20th February 1885. t There is no difTiculty in finding a number of instances in which tribes are divided by territorial boundaries. The Atchakzais are cut in two by the frontier between Pishin and Afghanistan at the Khojak. Of the Sunzakhel section of the Kakar Pathans, some are within our boundary, and others are independent. I believe it will be found that the Baretchis of Shorawak (Afghan) extend into Shorarud (British). The Sinjarani Biluchis are at Chageh subjects of Kelat, at Rudbar and thence to Chakansar subjects of Kabul. I should think it certain that the Afridis are divided. I have no doubt the same thing happens on the Perso-Baluch frontier. People like the Rinds, Rekis, and Damnis will probably be found on both sides the boundary. There is a considerable settlement near Muhsinabad, in Persia, of one of the Char Aimak of Herat, the Firuzkuhis I believe. The above instances are not quite on all fours with the cases of the Turkmans as stated by Russia. If I understand right, the contention is that the tribes being constantly on the move, no member can be said to be an inhabitant of one side or the other of any line drawn through the region within which they wander. But is this so ? I have always understood that (for instance) the Sariks of Yulatan were of a different section from the Sariks of Panjdeh, and that, though there was constant communication between the two places, there was no difficulty in distinguishing between a Yulatan and a Panjdeh Sarik. It is certain that during the last 18 months both Yulangtush Khan and Amin-ullah Khan (the Afghan Governors) have taken revenue from the Panjdeh Turkmans, and of course have not touched those of Yulatan. But if it is granted that the view of Russia is a correct one, it would be difficult perhaps to find an exact parallel on our frontier; so far, at least, as I know. The nearest approach would be the periodical migrations of the Brahuis from the plains of Katchi to the hills round Quetta. Many of the Pathan tribes move in like manner every year. But the Brahuis, if not in the strict sense of the word our subjects, are so completely under our control, whether they are actually in our territory or not, that no difficulty can possibly arise in settling any cases that may occur. The case of the Salors and Sariks, as stated by the Russians, obviously differs from the above, and presents, no doubt, greater difficulty, but I do not see that it is insuperable. J. R. mods.abstract: This file consists of a note written by J R Fitzgerald, First Assistant to the Agent to the Governor-General for Beluchistan, in which the author provides a number of instances of tribes divided by territorial boundaries, and casts doubt on the notion that members of those tribes cannot be said to be inhabitants of one side or the other of those boundaries.The file also reproduces an extract from a letter written by Her Majesty's Ambassador at Tehran, dated 26 December 1874, in which the author provides examples of nomadic tribes who migrate across boundary lines, but who nevertheless declare allegiance and pay tribute to one state or the other.
